one_liner: Kanban visualizes work to manage and improve the flow of tasks through a system, allowing teams to self-organize and adapt to changes.
how_it_works: Kanban uses a visual board to represent the workflow of tasks, helping teams to see the status of work items at a glance. By limiting the number of tasks in progress (WIP), it enhances efficiency and predictability. Teams continuously monitor and adjust their processes based on feedback, fostering a culture of iterative improvement and collaboration.

steps: 1. Visualize the workflow using a Kanban board.
2. Limit the number of work items in progress (WIP).
3. Manage flow by monitoring and adjusting the work process.
4. Make policies explicit to guide decision-making.
5. Implement feedback cycles to continuously improve the process.
6. Evolve the system collaboratively through experimentation.
algorithm.core_equation: output = improved workflow efficiency and service delivery
algorithm.input_format: Work items/tasks that need to be managed.
algorithm.output_format: Improved workflow efficiency and service delivery.

parameters.name: WIP limit
parameters.effect: Limiting WIP can enhance focus and reduce bottlenecks.

parameters.name: Feedback cycle frequency
parameters.effect: More frequent feedback can lead to quicker adjustments and improvements.

parameters.name: Visualization tools
parameters.effect: Effective visualization aids in tracking progress and identifying issues.

complexity.practical_note: Real-world performance can vary based on team size and complexity of workflows.

use_when: You need to manage complex workflows in software development.
Your team is facing challenges with project delivery timelines.
You want to implement a flexible and adaptive project management approach.
avoid_when: The project requires strict adherence to predefined methodologies.
You have a small team with very simple workflows.
The organization is not open to iterative improvements.
common_mistakes: Not setting appropriate WIP limits, leading to bottlenecks.
Failing to visualize the workflow effectively.
Ignoring feedback cycles, which can hinder improvement.

weaknesses: May not suit projects requiring strict methodologies.
Can become chaotic without proper management.
Requires cultural buy-in for effective implementation.

compared_to.verdict: Use Kanban for continuous flow and flexibility; use Scrum for structured sprints and roles.
